thread.section_title: Australian Business & World Finance News - Yahoo!7 Finance
thread.title: $A lower ahead of Greece talks

title: $A lower ahead of Greece talks
text:
Fri, Jul 10, 2015, 9:52 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A lower ahead of Greece talks AAP – 3 hours ago Print 
The Australian dollar is slightly lower as its recent rally eases ahead of the next round of Greek debt talks. 
At 1700 AEST on Friday, the local unit was trading at 74.69 US cents, down from 74.77 cents on Thursday. 
Earlier in the day it rose as high as 74.96 US cents, its strongest level since Tuesday. 
It fell to a new six year low of 73.72 US cents on Wednesday but has since recovered due to a bounce in Chinese shares and a strong local jobs report, OANDA Australia and Asia Pacific senior trader FX Stephen Innes said. 
The unemployment rate rose to six per cent in June, better than expectations of 6.1 per cent, while weeks of heavy falls on the Shanghai stock exchange appeared to have ended, at least for now. 
"Measures banning major shareholders from selling stakes in listed companies for six months clearly improved investor sentiment," Mr Innes said. 
However, the Australian dollar's rally is losing steam as traders await weekend negotiations between Greece and her creditors, Mr Innes added. 
Greece is believe to have made some concessions on austerity measures in order to get more bailout funds. 
"Traders for the most part continue to favour the sidelines, creating lower liquidity conditions than normal," Mr Innes said. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 91.00 Japanese yen, up from Thursday's close of 90.70 yen, and at 67.35 euro cents, down from 67.42 euro cents. 
The Australian bond market was weaker, and Westpac senior market strategist Damien McColough said increased market confidence was mostly due to the turnaround on the Chinese market. 
"Thirty six hours ago we were pushing up towards our recent highs in our futures contracts," he said. 
"If the Chinese stock market continued to collapse we would have been into some high elevated prices, which wouldn't have matched our fundamentals." 
Mr McColough said the bond market sell off is unlikely to be extended as European and US markets head into the weekend. 
He said traders will want to move to safer investments in case the Greek talks turn sour. 
At 1630 AEST, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.015 (implying a yield of 2.985 per cent), down from 97.150 (2.850 per cent) on Thursday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.020 (1.980 per cent), down from 98.100 (1.900 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Joyce backed over stopping mine AAP
